title: The impact of the early environment on oxytocin receptor epigenetics and potential therapeutic implications
affiliations: Department of Neurology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
Department of Pediatrics, Division of Neonatology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
background: Oxytocin's role in social behavior and psychopathology is highly variable, and epigenetic modifications to the oxytocin receptor gene (OXTR) may improve our understanding and therapeutic approaches.
hypotheses: Early life environment shapes OXTR epigenetics and impacts social-developmental outcomes.
OXTR methylation (OXTRm) serves as a predictive mechanism for neurodevelopmental outcomes.
OXTRm can serve as a powerful target for therapeutic interventions to improve oxytocin therapeutics.
major_findings: Early life experiences, such as maternal care, significantly influence OXTRm in both animal models and humans.
OXTRm is highly variable across individuals and is associated with differences in social behavior and psychopathology.
Specific CpG sites within the OXTR promoter region are functionally related to OXTR expression and are consistently associated with behavioral outcomes across species.
OXTRm may impact additional cellular mechanisms, such as the perinatal GABA switch, with therapeutic potential.
Early life therapies targeting OXTRm may improve the therapeutic potential of exogenous oxytocin.
